description: high +â€Ž ball, of the same railroad origins as lowball.

entries.meaning: A cocktail made from a spirit plus soda water etc.
(rail transport, US) An all clear or full speed ahead signal.
(climbing) A very high bouldering problem, often with a hard landing.
examples: Austrian all rounder Alex Luger climbs what he describes as a highball boulder problem and what most people would call a solo.
It's great for serving heavier drinks in. Highballs and pint glasses are excellent substitutes.

verbs.description: highball (third-person singular simple present highballs, present participle highballing, simple past and past participle highballed)

entries.meaning: To make an estimate which tends toward exaggeration.
examples: If we highball the price, it comes out to $240. If we lowball it, it's closer to $200.

entries.meaning: (US, slang, possibly dated) To move quickly; to hightail.
examples: Booster-equipped 628 highballs west at Glen Lake, Minn., back in 1947.
